examples.title:
OS‑level
  modal triggered only when an app first calls the camera API; options: “Allow
  Once”, “Allow While Using App”, “Don’t Allow”.
examples.use_case:
Any iOS
  app needing camera for photos, AR, or video.
examples.why_selected:
Illustrates
  granular, time‑bounded consent and contextual purpose string supplied by
  developer.
examples.pbd_alignment:
Proactive, Privacy
  as default, Respect for user privacy
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
User
  control & freedom; Visibility of system status

examples.title:
Full‑screen
  dialog with “While using the app / Only this time / Don’t allow”. Denial
  results in SECURITY_EXCEPTION.
examples.use_case:
Android
  apps recording video or scanning QR codes.
examples.why_selected:
Demonstrates
  symmetrical design with OS‑wide permission dashboard for later revocation.

examples.title:
URL‑bar
  chip + dropdown (“Allow / Block”) appears when site calls getUserMedia({ video:true }); icon
  persists while active.
examples.use_case:
Web
  conferencing apps (e.g., Google Meet, Teams, Zoom).
examples.why_selected:
Non‑modal,
  site‑specific decision with persistent indicator and quick revoke.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Recognition
  rather than recall; Aesthetic & minimalist design

examples.title:
In‑app
  explanatory screen precedes OS dialog, explaining need for camera with
  illustrative graphic and CTA “Turn On”.
examples.use_case:
Social
  media encouraging real‑time video capture.
examples.why_selected:
Shows
  rationale‑before‑request pattern that improves accept rates without dark
  patterns.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Match
  between system & real world; Help users recognize, diagnose, recover

examples.title:
Immersive
  overlay requesting permission to record and stream passthrough; “Allow / Deny
  / Always Allow”.
examples.why_selected:
Highlights
  emerging AR/VR context where camera covers entire environment; stresses
  explicit, revocable consent.
examples.pbd_alignment:
End‑to‑End
  security, Respect for user privacy

examples.title:
Two-step
  flow: (1) Download archive (JSON/HTML) via wizard; (2) Permanent delete or
  temporary deactivate. Clear warnings, progress meter, and email receipts.
examples.use_case:
Social
  networks with rich personal data, photos, connections.

examples.title:
Multi‑select
  list of 50+ Google services, push or pull export (email link, Drive),
  multiple formats (JSON, MBOX). Separate “Delete a Google Service” panel.
examples.use_case:
Cloud
  ecosystems spanning mail, photos, docs, etc.
examples.why_selected:
Exemplifies
  scalable multi‑service export with progress email and queue status.
examples.pbd_alignment:
Full
  functionality, Respect for user privacy
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Flexibility
  & efficiency; Visibility of system status

examples.title:
In‑app
  help flow opens browser wizard: verify email, confirm, five‑day cooling
  period. CSV/JSON export for playlists & listening history.
examples.use_case:
Subscription
  media service retaining long‑term behavioural data.
examples.why_selected:
Showcases
  cooling‑off window and reversible deletion aligning with dark‑pattern
  avoidance.

examples.title:
Authenticated
  web portal with “Get a copy of your data” wizard and one‑click “Delete your
  account”. Provides estimate of file size and time.
examples.use_case:
Device +
  services vendor where Apple ID spans multiple platforms.
examples.why_selected:
Uses
  plain‑language explanation, estimated wait times, and real‑time status
  tracking.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Aesthetic
  & minimalist design; Visibility of system status

examples.title:
Deactivation
  screen in Settings: warns deletion after
  30 days; provides link to “Request Your Archive” beforehand.
examples.use_case:
Micro‑blogging
  networks holding large public posting history.
examples.why_selected:
Highlights
  interplay between deactivation grace period and export; warns dependencies
  (ads, analytics).
